awd_titl_txt: Topology of 4-manifolds, links and Engel groups
awd_abstract_narration:
Topology of manifolds is a subject aimed at classification of shapes (manifolds) which are locally modeled on the Euclidean space of a given dimension. The topology of 4-dimensional manifolds is of particular interest since this dimension is relevant in physics while studying space-time, and it is the subject of some of the outstanding open problems in Topology. This dimension is also special in the sense that it is borderline between "low dimensions" where many classification results have been settled and "higher dimensions" where geometric classification problems are known to admit an algebraic reformulation. This project is aimed at classification up to continuous deformations of 4-manifolds with special characteristics, known as large fundamental groups. 

The main part of this project concerns geometric classification of topological 4-manifolds, specifically the topological surgery conjecture and the s-cobordism conjecture for "large" fundamental groups. The notion of a 1/2-null surgery problem is proposed, as an intermediate step in the context of universal surgery problems. A key ingredient is the group-theoretic Engel relation, which is closely related to higher-order singularities of surfaces in 4-manifolds. The framework of the AB-slice problem is also considered. Another part of the project concerns ongoing work on applications of (2+1)-dimensional topological quantum field theories to combinatorics and to representations of mapping class groups. The PI also plans to consider questions in geometric and topological complexity of embeddings in dimension 4.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit. The study of topological 4-dimensional manifolds is a subject on the borderline between higher dimensional topology, where tools for geometric classification have been developed in the 1960s, and low-dimensional topology where some of the classification questions remain outstanding open problems. Four-dimensional manifolds with trivial fundamental group (where any loop can be contracted) have been classified from the topological perspective by Michael Freedman in the early 1980s. The extent to which these techniques work without fundamental group restrictions has been a main research focus of the PI.

In collaboration with M. Freedman the PI used group-theoretic Engel relations to approach problems in geometric classification theory, in particular surgery theory for topological 4-manifolds. A new collection of surgery problems was introduced, which are universal in the sense that solving them is equivalent to solving any 4-dimensional surgery problem. This narrowed the gap between the main open question and the surgery problems which are known to admit a solution. In another direction, a collection of links was constructed which are universal for 4-dimensional surgery and which admit Seifert surfaces with trivial Lagrangian. The result was unexpected, given recent work in the subject which showed that links which satisfy a slightly stronger condition, trivial+, are slice. These results show that the distinction between trivial and trivial+ is crucial for resolving the surgery conjecture. 

Another research direction of the PI concerned problems at the intersection of quantum topology and combinatorics. In collaboration with I. Agol, the PI used ideas from quantum topology to generalize results of Tutte on combinatorics of planar and non-planar graphs. The analogue of Tutte's golden identity was established for the Yamada polynomial (the SO(3) quantum invariant) of cubic graphs in 3-space. In collaboration with P. Fendley, a relation was established between the trace evaluation in SO(3) topological quantum field theory and evaluations of a topological Tutte polynomial. This is the first connection between the subject of topological graph polynomials (for graphs on surfaces) and topological quantum field theory. As an application, a generalization of the remarkable Tutte golden identity was proved for graphs on the torus. 

Broader impacts. While supported by this grant, the PI supervised 4 Ph.D. students working on 4-manifold topology, link homology theories and their stable homotopy refinements, and hyperbolic knot theory. The PI mentored several research projects by undergraduate students. In 2017 the PI founded the University of Virginia Math Circle, an outreach program for elementary and middle school students; the PI has been the principal instructor in this annual program.
